Hi Jim, thanks for the background. If not Ainu, I am very curious 
what the origin of a koshirae like this would be. Perhaps someone 
simply cobbled this together from the fragments of other koshirae? 
Or, maybe this piece originated outside of Japan. I am sure it would 
be instructive to see the blade...

- Ray

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...> 
wrote:

> The metal fittings of the lot you linked to are not what I think of 
as either Ezo or Ainu, in any usual usage.  The little loop fitting 
makes me think of a late toppei koshirae (the type made for wear with 
Western dress).  The saya decoration is very unusual, as is the 
kashira shape.  The tsuba and kojiri seem to be fillers.  It's a 
koshirae that I'd like to look into more.
> 
> Let me know if you have more questions, since this is pretty mixed 
up.
> Jim
> 
> 
>   Jim, the Ezo koshirae is very interesting to me too. Can you give 
>   some background on group? I had been under the misimpression that 
>   these pieces were Ainu...
> 
>   http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/search/alt_images.asp?
>   lObjectID=4179742
> 
>   Thanks,
>   Ray
>
